Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: RUI: ARTS: Revisionary systematics of herbivorous sea slugs: identifying traits that promote diversification and morphological novelty.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sea slugs of the genus Sacoglossa exhibit an array of unusual traits that may confer an evolutionary advantage. For example, some sea slugs species are 'solar-powered,' like plants, as they can harvest and sequester functional photosynthetic chloroplasts after feeding on algae. This kleptoplastic ability, along with other traits, may account for their high diversification rate and species richness. In this project, the researchers will combine genetic, anatomic, ecological and developmental studies to describe over 100 new species of sea slugs. Modeling will then identify factors that determine how species are distributed, and what makes some sacoglossans more ecologically and evolutionary diverse than others.

Marine biodiversity is increasingly threatened by human activities and climate change, yet actual biodiversity richness is not reflected by the scientific names in many groups, hampering conservation efforts. Anti-cancer compounds have been isolated from some saccoglossans, and others have served as biological control agents for invasive algae, but taxonomic uncertainty has limited the potential for their use in these roles. To fully leverage an improved understanding of this biodiversity resource, this project will train the next generation of taxonomists at two Hispanic and predominantly undergraduate serving institutions and during an international workshop, develop web-based resources, and provide new insight into factors that govern diversity in marine ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sacoglossa is a group of sea slugs famed for the remarkable ability of some species to keep chloroplasts from the algae they eat alive inside their body, becoming photosynthetic animals. We found strong support that this group is the closest relative of air-breathing snails and slugs, the most species-rich group of animals outside of the insects, and could therefore yield insight into how land snails evolved from ocean-dwelling relatives. We used DNA sequencing and studies of microscopic internal structures to discover 100 new species thus far in the Sacoglossa, previously unrecognized by science. That is a high proportion of undescribed diversity, as this group had only about 300 named species when we began. We are proceeding to give scientific names to, and fully describe, all the newly discovered species. We also place all species in a phylogeny or ?family tree? using DNA sequence information, and use those relationships to test hypotheses about how speciation and extinction influence the relative species richness of different subgroups.

Our findings of so many unrecognized (cryptic) species have important implications in several fields. The nominal ?species? Elysia ?ornata? is the source of kahalalides, drugs that are currently in clinical trials as potential new anticancer medications, as well as possible antiviral and antifungal agents. Our work showed that specimens called ?E. ornata? are actually 11 different species, hard to tell apart but each distinct. We do not know which of these species were the actual source of known kahalalides, or which have not yet been studied for new possible drugs with different anticancer or antiviral properties; these findings therefore have substantial implications for drug discovery efforts focusing on marine natural resources.

Some of the groups we studied are also important as the only organisms that feed on highly toxic and invasive algae that are taking over large areas, including Caulerpa taxifolia and Avrainvillea amadelpha. However, these slugs are generally considered to be non-selective, feeding on diverse species of Caulerpa and therefore not very effective as biological control agents that could control outbreaks of one invasive species like C. taxifolia. We tested the alternative possibility: that nominal ?species? of Caulerpa feeders were actually complexes of unrecognized but distinct species, each specializing on different kinds of Caulerpa. We found that both ?Oxynoe viridis? and ?E. tomentosa? each comprised seven different species in the Pacific Ocean; in each case, the seven new Oxynoe species and the seven different Elysia species had distinct preferences for which Caulerpa species they would feed on. These findings show that failure to distinguish hard-to-recognize species can impair our ability to find good candidates for biological control, or to predict how a local community may respond to an algal invasion. We also found three undescribed species consuming the hugely invasive A. amadepha, which has taken over large areas of Oahu, Hawaii. This research may help to manage outbreaks of invasive algal species.

To better understand the origins of marine biodiversity, we used our data to explore the factors that explain why some group (for instance, the genus Elysia) can have over 100 species, whereas others (the genus Roburnella) have only one surviving species. We found that lineages feeding on less toxic or less crunchy seaweed diversified into more species over evolutionary time than lineages that feed on toxic or calcified algae; the feeding ecology of a group can thus influence speciation and extinction dynamics over long periods. We also found that groups producing highly dispersive, planktonic offspring ultimately out-speciate groups that switched to non-dispersive offspring, which remain near their hatching site; this was the opposite of 40 years of predictions based on the snail fossil record, but is consistent with DNA-based phylogenies of most marine invertebrate groups. Work on a handful of species that can produce either dispersive or non-dispersive larvae in different places or times indicates that regions where dispersal is unlikely due to ocean currents tends to favor non-dispersive offspring, but this in turn reduces genetic diversity and impedes outcrossing with other populations, which can doom a population in the long run.
